t: Job 1
There*p was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, and one that feared God, and eschewed evil.
And*p there were born unto him seven sons and three daughters.

His*p substance also was seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she asses, and a very great household; so that this man was the greatest of all the men of the east.
And*p his sons went and feasted in their houses, every one his day; and sent and called for their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.

And*p it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt offerings according to the number of them all: for Job said, It may be that my sons have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.
Now*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan came also among them.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? Then Satan answered the Lord,*s and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil?
Then*p Satan answered the Lord,*s and said, Doth Job fear God for nought?
Hast*p not thou made an hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he hath on every side? thou hast blessed the work of his hands, and his substance is increased in the land.
But*p put forth thine hand now, and touch all that he hath, and he will curse thee to thy face.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, Behold, all that he hath is in thy power; only upon himself put not forth thine hand. So Satan went forth from the presence of the Lord.*s
And*p there was a day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house:
And*p there came a messenger unto Job, and said, The oxen were plowing, and the asses feeding beside them:
And*p the Sabeans fell upon them, and took them away; yea, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.

While*p he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The fire of God is fallen from heaven, and hath burned up the sheep, and the servants, and consumed them; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.

While*p he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The Chaldeans made out three bands, and fell upon the camels, and have carried them away, yea, and slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
While*p he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, Thy sons and thy daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house:
And,*p behold, there came a great wind from the wilderness, and smote the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young men, and they are dead; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
Then*p Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and fell down upon the ground, and worshipped,
And*p said, Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither: the Lord*s gave, and the Lord*s hath taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord.*s
In*p all this Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly.
Job 2
Again*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan came also among them to present himself before the Lord.*s
And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, From whence comest thou? And Satan answered the Lord,*s and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil? and still he holdeth fast his integrity, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause.
And*p Satan answered the Lord,*s and said, Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life.
But*p put forth thine hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse thee to thy face.
And*p the Lord*s said unto Satan, Behold, he is in thine hand; but save his life.
So*p went Satan forth from the presence of the Lord,*s and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his foot unto his crown.
And*p he took him a potsherd to scrape himself withal; and he sat down among the ashes.
Then*p said his wife unto him, Dost thou still retain thine integrity? curse God, and die.
But*p he said unto her, Thou speakest as one of the foolish women speaketh. What? shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil? In all this did not Job sin with his lips.

Now*p when Job's three friends heard of all this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place; Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite: for they had made an appointment together to come to mourn with him and to comfort him.
And*p when they lifted up their eyes afar off, and knew him not, they lifted up their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his mantle, and sprinkled dust upon their heads toward heaven.
So*p they sat down with him upon the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spake a word unto him: for they saw that his grief was very great.
Job 3
After*p this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
And*p Job spake, and said,
Let*p the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived.
Let*p that day be darkness; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.
Let*p darkness and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dwell upon it; let the blackness of the day terrify it.
As*p for that night, let darkness seize upon it; let it not be joined unto the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months.
Lo,*p let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein.
Let*p them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning.
Let*p the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look for light, but have none; neither let it see the dawning of the day:
Because*p it shut not up the doors of my mother's womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.
Why*p died I not from the womb? why did I not give up the ghost when I came out of the belly?
Why*p did the knees prevent me? or why the breasts that I should suck?
For*p now should I have lain still and been quiet, I should have slept: then had I been at rest,
With*p kings and counsellors of the earth, which built desolate places for themselves;
Or*p with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver:
Or*p as an hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants which never saw light.
There*p the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary be at rest.
There*p the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
The*p small and great are there; and the servant is free from his master.
Wherefore*p is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the bitter in soul;
Which*p long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
Which*p rejoice exceedingly, and are glad, when they can find the grave?
Why*p is light given to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
For*p my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters.
For*p the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me.
I*p was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.
Job 4
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
If*p we assay to commune with thee, wilt thou be grieved? but who can withhold himself from speaking?
Behold,*p thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands.
Thy*p words have upholden him that was falling, and thou hast strengthened the feeble knees.
But*p now it is come upon thee, and thou faintest; it toucheth thee, and thou art troubled.
Is*p not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy hope, and the uprightness of thy ways?
Remember,*p I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent? or where were the righteous cut off?
Even*p as I have seen, they that plow iniquity, and sow wickedness, reap the same.
By*p the blast of God they perish, and by the breath of his nostrils are they consumed.
The*p roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions, are broken.
The*p old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the stout lion's whelps are scattered abroad.
Now*p a thing was secretly brought to me, and mine ear received a little thereof.
In*p thoughts from the visions of the night, when deep sleep falleth on men,
Fear*p came upon me, and trembling, which made all my bones to shake.
Then*p a spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood up:
It*p stood still, but I could not discern the form thereof: an image was before mine eyes, there was silence, and I heard a voice, saying,
Shall*p mortal man be more just than God? shall a man be more pure than his maker?
Behold,*p he put no trust in his servants; and his angels he charged with folly:
How*p much less in them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, which are crushed before the moth?
They*p are destroyed from morning to evening: they perish for ever without any regarding it.
Doth*p not their excellency which is in them go away? they die, even without wisdom.
Job 5
Call*p now, if there be any that will answer thee; and to which of the saints wilt thou turn?
For*p wrath killeth the foolish man, and envy slayeth the silly one.
I*p have seen the foolish taking root: but suddenly I cursed his habitation.
His*p children are far from safety, and they are crushed in the gate, neither is there any to deliver them.
Whose*p harvest the hungry eateth up, and taketh it even out of the thorns, and the robber swalloweth up their substance.
Although*p affliction cometh not forth of the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground;
Yet*p man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward.
I*p would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause:
Which*p doeth great things and unsearchable; marvellous things without number:
Who*p giveth rain upon the earth, and sendeth waters upon the fields:
To*p set up on high those that be low; that those which mourn may be exalted to safety.
He*p disappointeth the devices of the crafty, so that their hands cannot perform their enterprise.
He*p taketh the wise in their own craftiness: and the counsel of the froward is carried headlong.
They*p meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope in the noonday as in the night.
But*p he saveth the poor from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
So*p the poor hath hope, and iniquity stoppeth her mouth.
Behold,*p happy is the man whom God correcteth: therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty:
For*p he maketh sore, and bindeth up: he woundeth, and his hands make whole.
He*p shall deliver thee in six troubles: yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.
In*p famine he shall redeem thee from death: and in war from the power of the sword.
Thou*p shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue: neither shalt thou be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
At*p destruction and famine thou shalt laugh: neither shalt thou be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
For*p thou shalt be in league with the stones of the field: and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.
And*p thou shalt know that thy tabernacle shall be in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin.
Thou*p shalt know also that thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth.
Thou*p shalt come to thy grave in a full age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season.
Lo*p this, we have searched it, so it is; hear it, and know thou it for thy good.
Job 6
But*p Job answered and said,
Oh*p that my grief were thoroughly weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together!
For*p now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swallowed up.
For*p the arrows of the Almighty are within me, the poison whereof drinketh up my spirit: the terrors of God do set themselves in array against me.
Doth*p the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox over his fodder?
Can*p that which is unsavoury be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
The*p things that my soul refused to touch are as my sorrowful meat.
Oh*p that I might have my request; and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
Even*p that it would please God to destroy me; that he would let loose his hand, and cut me off!
Then*p should I yet have comfort; yea, I would harden myself in sorrow: let him not spare; for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
What*p is my strength, that I should hope? and what is mine end, that I should prolong my life?
Is*p my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?
Is*p not my help in me? and is wisdom driven quite from me?
To*p him that is afflicted pity should be shewed from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
My*p brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook, and as the stream of brooks they pass away;
Which*p are blackish by reason of the ice, and wherein the snow is hid:
What*p time they wax warm, they vanish: when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.
The*p paths of their way are turned aside; they go to nothing, and perish.
The*p troops of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba waited for them.
They*p were confounded because they had hoped; they came thither, and were ashamed.
For*p now ye are nothing; ye see my casting down, and are afraid.
Did*p I say, Bring unto me? or, Give a reward for me of your substance?
Or,*p Deliver me from the enemy's hand? or, Redeem me from the hand of the mighty?
Teach*p me, and I will hold my tongue: and cause me to understand wherein I have erred.
How*p forcible are right words! but what doth your arguing reprove?
Do*p ye imagine to reprove words, and the speeches of one that is desperate, which are as wind?
Yea,*p ye overwhelm the fatherless, and ye dig a pit for your friend.
Now*p therefore be content, look upon me; for it is evident unto you if I lie.
Return,*p I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yea, return again, my righteousness is in it.
Is*p there iniquity in my tongue? cannot my taste discern perverse things?
Job 7
Is*p there not an appointed time to man upon earth? are not his days also like the days of an hireling?
As*p a servant earnestly desireth the shadow, and as an hireling looketh for the reward of his work:
So*p am I made to possess months of vanity, and wearisome nights are appointed to me.
When*p I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone? and I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
My*p flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust; my skin is broken, and become loathsome.
My*p days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle, and are spent without hope.
O*p remember that my life is wind: mine eye shall no more see good.
The*p eye of him that hath seen me shall see me no more: thine eyes are upon me, and I am not.
As*p the cloud is consumed and vanisheth away: so he that goeth down to the grave shall come up no more.
He*p shall return no more to his house, neither shall his place know him any more.
Therefore*p I will not refrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*p I a sea, or a whale, that thou settest a watch over me?
When*p I say, My bed shall comfort me, my couch shall ease my complaint;
Then*p thou scarest me with dreams, and terrifiest me through visions:
So*p that my soul chooseth strangling, and death rather than my life.
I*p loathe it; I would not live alway: let me alone; for my days are vanity.
What*p is man, that thou shouldest magnify him? and that thou shouldest set thine heart upon him?
And*p that thou shouldest visit him every morning, and try him every moment?
How*p long wilt thou not depart from me, nor let me alone till I swallow down my spittle?
I*p have sinned; what shall I do unto thee, O thou preserver of men? why hast thou set me as a mark against thee, so that I am a burden to myself?
And*p why dost thou not pardon my transgression, and take away mine iniquity? for now shall I sleep in the dust; and thou shalt seek me in the morning, but I shall not be.
Job 8
Then*p answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
How*p long wilt thou speak these things? and how long shall the words of thy mouth be like a strong wind?
Doth*p God pervert judgment? or doth the Almighty pervert justice?
If*p thy children have sinned against him, and he have cast them away for their transgression;
If*p thou wouldest seek unto God betimes, and make thy supplication to the Almighty;
If*p thou wert pure and upright; surely now he would awake for thee, and make the habitation of thy righteousness prosperous.
Though*p thy beginning was small, yet thy latter end should greatly increase.
For*p enquire, I pray thee, of the former age, and prepare thyself to the search of their fathers:
(For*p we are but of yesterday, and know nothing, because our days upon earth are a shadow:)
Shall*p not they teach thee, and tell thee, and utter words out of their heart?
Can*p the rush grow up without mire? can the flag grow without water?
Whilst*p it is yet in his greenness, and not cut down, it withereth before any other herb.
So*p are the paths of all that forget God; and the hypocrite's hope shall perish:
Whose*p hope shall be cut off, and whose trust shall be a spider's web.
He*p shall lean upon his house, but it shall not stand: he shall hold it fast, but it shall not endure.
He*p is green before the sun, and his branch shooteth forth in his garden.
His*p roots are wrapped about the heap, and seeth the place of stones.
If*p he destroy him from his place, then it shall deny him, saying, I have not seen thee.
Behold,*p this is the joy of his way, and out of the earth shall others grow.
Behold,*p God will not cast away a perfect man, neither will he help the evil doers:
Till*p he fill thy mouth with laughing, and thy lips with rejoicing.
They*p that hate thee shall be clothed with shame; and the dwelling place of the wicked shall come to nought.
Job 9
Then*p Job answered and said,
I*p know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God?
If*p he will contend with him, he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
He*p is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?
Which*p removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger.
Which*p shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
Which*p commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
Which*p alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
Which*p maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
Which*p doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number.
Lo,*p he goeth by me, and I see him not: he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
Behold,*p he taketh away, who can hinder him? who will say unto him, What doest thou?
If*p God will not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stoop under him.
How*p much less shall I answer him, and choose out my words to reason with him?
Whom,*p though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make supplication to my judge.
If*p I had called, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
For*p he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
He*p will not suffer me to take my breath, but filleth me with bitterness.
If*p I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?
If*p I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
Though*p I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life.
This*p is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
If*p the scourge slay suddenly, he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
The*p earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he?
Now*p my days are swifter than a post: they flee away, they see no good.
They*p are passed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
If*p I say, I will forget my complaint, I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
I*p am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
If*p I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?
If*p I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
Yet*p shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
For*p he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment.
Neither*p is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
Let*p him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear terrify me:
Then*p would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me.
Job 10
My*p soul is weary of my life; I will leave my complaint upon myself; I will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*p will say unto God, Do not condemn me; shew me wherefore thou contendest with me.
Is*p it good unto thee that thou shouldest oppress, that thou shouldest despise the work of thine hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
Hast*p thou eyes of flesh? or seest thou as man seeth?
Are*p thy days as the days of man? are thy years as man's days,
That*p thou enquirest after mine iniquity, and searchest after my sin?
Thou*p knowest that I am not wicked; and there is none that can deliver out of thine hand.
Thine*p hands have made me and fashioned me together round about; yet thou dost destroy me.
Remember,*p I beseech thee, that thou hast made me as the clay; and wilt thou bring me into dust again?
Hast*p thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese?
Thou*p hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and hast fenced me with bones and sinews.
Thou*p hast granted me life and favour, and thy visitation hath preserved my spirit.
And*p these things hast thou hid in thine heart: I know that this is with thee.
If*p I sin, then thou markest me, and thou wilt not acquit me from mine iniquity.
If*p I be wicked, woe unto me; and if I be righteous, yet will I not lift up my head. I am full of confusion; therefore see thou mine affliction;
For*p it increaseth. Thou huntest me as a fierce lion: and again thou shewest thyself marvellous upon me.
Thou*p renewest thy witnesses against me, and increasest thine indignation upon me; changes and war are against me.
Wherefore*p then hast thou brought me forth out of the womb? Oh that I had given up the ghost, and no eye had seen me!
I*p should have been as though I had not been; I should have been carried from the womb to the grave.
Are*p not my days few? cease then, and let me alone, that I may take comfort a little,
Before*p I go whence I shall not return, even to the land of darkness and the shadow of death;
A*p land of darkness, as darkness itself; and of the shadow of death, without any order, and where the light is as darkness.
Job 11
Then*p answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
Should*p not the multitude of words be answered? and should a man full of talk be justified?
Should*p thy lies make men hold their peace? and when thou mockest, shall no man make thee ashamed?
For*p thou hast said, My doctrine is pure, and I am clean in thine eyes.
But*p oh that God would speak, and open his lips against thee;
And*p that he would shew thee the secrets of wisdom, that they are double to that which is! Know therefore that God exacteth of thee less than thine iniquity deserveth.
Canst*p thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the Almighty unto perfection?
It*p is as high as heaven; what canst thou do? deeper than hell; what canst thou know?
The*p measure thereof is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea.
If*p he cut off, and shut up, or gather together, then who can hinder him?
For*p he knoweth vain men: he seeth wickedness also; will he not then consider it?
For*p vain man would be wise, though man be born like a wild ass's colt.
If*p thou prepare thine heart, and stretch out thine hands toward him;
If*p iniquity be in thine hand, put it far away, and let not wickedness dwell in thy tabernacles.
For*p then shalt thou lift up thy face without spot; yea, thou shalt be stedfast, and shalt not fear:
Because*p thou shalt forget thy misery, and remember it as waters that pass away:
And*p thine age shall be clearer than the noonday; thou shalt shine forth, thou shalt be as the morning.
And*p thou shalt be secure, because there is hope; yea, thou shalt dig about thee, and thou shalt take thy rest in safety.
Also*p thou shalt lie down, and none shall make thee afraid; yea, many shall make suit unto thee.
But*p the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and they shall not escape, and their hope shall be as the giving up of the ghost.
Job 12
And*p Job answered and said,
No*p doubt but ye are the people, and wisdom shall die with you.
But*p I have understanding as well as you; I am not inferior to you: yea, who knoweth not such things as these?
I*p am as one mocked of his neighbour, who calleth upon God, and he answereth him: the just upright man is laughed to scorn.
He*p that is ready to slip with his feet is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
The*p tabernacles of robbers prosper, and they that provoke God are secure; into whose hand God bringeth abundantly.
But*p ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee; and the fowls of the air, and they shall tell thee:
Or*p speak to the earth, and it shall teach thee: and the fishes of the sea shall declare unto thee.
Who*p knoweth not in all these that the hand of the Lord*s hath wrought this?
In*p whose hand is the soul of every living thing, and the breath of all mankind.
Doth*p not the ear try words? and the mouth taste his meat?
With*p the ancient is wisdom; and in length of days understanding.
With*p him is wisdom and strength, he hath counsel and understanding.
Behold,*p he breaketh down, and it cannot be built again: he shutteth up a man, and there can be no opening.
Behold,*p he withholdeth the waters, and they dry up: also he sendeth them out, and they overturn the earth.
With*p him is strength and wisdom: the deceived and the deceiver are his.
He*p leadeth counsellors away spoiled, and maketh the judges fools.
He*p looseth the bond of kings, and girdeth their loins with a girdle.
He*p leadeth princes away spoiled, and overthroweth the mighty.
He*p removeth away the speech of the trusty, and taketh away the understanding of the aged.
He*p poureth contempt upon princes, and weakeneth the strength of the mighty.
He*p discovereth deep things out of darkness, and bringeth out to light the shadow of death.
He*p increaseth the nations, and destroyeth them: he enlargeth the nations, and straiteneth them again.
He*p taketh away the heart of the chief of the people of the earth, and causeth them to wander in a wilderness where there is no way.
They*p grope in the dark without light, and he maketh them to stagger like a drunken man.
Job 13
Lo,*p mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and understood it.
What*p ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you.
Surely*p I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
But*p ye are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.
O*p that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.
Hear*p now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
Will*p ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?
Will*p ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?
Is*p it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him?
He*p will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.
Shall*p not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?
Your*p remembrances are like unto ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.
Hold*p your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.
Wherefore*p do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in mine hand?
Though*p he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain mine own ways before him.
He*p also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrite shall not come before him.
Hear*p diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.
Behold*p now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.
Who*p is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall give up the ghost.
Only*p do not two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
Withdraw*p thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.
